I hope we take a moment today to reflect on this extraordinary achievement. Thanks to the thousands of Americans at @nasa and partners that made this launch possible and who will guide our nation through this new era. You have inspired millions. Now let the discovery begin. END http://pbs.twimg.com/media/Fhr39XzXEAAftsN.jpg

But we cannot ignore the profound ripples that this science has across our broader society. We feel that today as we looked towards launchpad 39B. I felt it as I watched the big eyes of my boys fill with possibility as they watched video of the rocket launch.13/14 http://pbs.twimg.com/media/Fhr38wIWYAAg7V-.jpg

But to say all this does not mean our efforts are symbolic or performative. Far from it. The science we seek is real and the impact of this exploration is limitless. Real advancements like  enabling GPS, LEDs, CAT scans, camera phones, and even advancements in baby formula.12/14 http://pbs.twimg.com/media/Fhr38VxXwAA1rQH.jpg

This first photograph of the Earthrise over the moon helped fuel the modern environmental conservation movement that has given rise a global call to tackle the dangers of climate change. It showed Earth not as a stage for superpowers, but as vulnerable and improbable. 11/14 http://pbs.twimg.com/media/Fhr38BcWQAQ68wc.jpg

Our greatest accomplishments in space ironically also teach us about our own fragility. We build massive rockets and telescopes that then show us how small we really are. But the perspective gives us humility. That we are a part of something bigger than all of us. 10/14 http://pbs.twimg.com/media/Fhr37moX0AA2TFJ.jpg

So what is it that is so powerful about this accomplishment today? Over my 4 yrs in Congress, I‚Äôve encountered nearly every facet of our nation‚Äôs work. One thing stands out about Artemis, the Webb Telescope, and our space program - a perspective that gives rise to humility. 9/14 http://pbs.twimg.com/media/Fhr37QgWQAE7dqa.jpg

But what is similar to Apollo era is a sense of deep division throughout our society and world. The pollution of politics invades nearly every facet of life. Sometimes it feels like we are becoming a nation addicted to anger, and we wonder if anything can snap us out of this.8/14 http://pbs.twimg.com/media/Fhr367CWYAcx6rH.jpg http://pbs.twimg.com/media/Fhr367CWAAEm8Ze.jpg

22,475 days since Alan Shepard first left our atmosphere, we return to the moon, but not as part of a space race that doubles as a defining proxy battle between superpowers. Our work in space need not be reactive to what‚Äôs happening on the ground. 7/14 http://pbs.twimg.com/media/Fhr36SPXEAMglu5.jpg http://pbs.twimg.com/media/Fhr36SNWIAAIQrx.jpg

As we head back to the moon for the first time in 50 yrs, I can‚Äôt help but reflect on the fact that Apollo and Artemis both occurred in eras of great turmoil and instability in our nation and around the globe. These moments though are different and the missions divergent. 6/14 http://pbs.twimg.com/media/Fhr35tiXEAYUSjH.jpg http://pbs.twimg.com/media/Fhr35tdX0AQMUrw.jpg

So as we see this rocket defy gravity with thrust never before achieved, the question of our level of inspiration has less to do with the magnificence of the feat and more to do with us and what mindset we bring to the equation. What is our conception of possibility? 5/14 http://pbs.twimg.com/media/Fhr35SHWIAIri4r.jpg

To have what amounts to a 32-story skyscraper that weighs nearly 6 million pounds lift off the ground at a speed of 22,600 mph and aimed to precisely enter the moon‚Äôs orbit 240,000 miles away and use that gravity to slingshot a capsule beyond the previous reaches of humanity.4/14 http://pbs.twimg.com/media/Fhr348DXEAQiXe2.jpg

An incredible, historic moment for NASA and for the USA. With this launch success, Artemis I is on course to complete tests of the integrated Space Launch System and Orion crew module, which will take us back to the Moon and lay the groundwork for the human exploration of Mars. https://twitter.com/nasaartemis/status/1592786755500986369 QT @NASAArtemis When we go, we go together.

The #Artemis team wants to thank everyone who helped us along the way toward the first launch of the @NASA_SLS rocket and @NASA_Orion. http://pbs.twimg.com/amplify_video_thumb/1592786707551866880/img/LQ75VretJ0y_yp3O.jpg https://video.twimg.com/amplify_video/1592786707551866880/vid/480x270/8JKksj5hyO7a1-eg.mp4?tag=14

One‚Äôs capacity to be inspired occurs precisely at the intersection of witnessing genuine groundbreaking feats and the capacity of one‚Äôs own conception of what is possible to expand. On one end I can assure you today‚Äôs achievement marks one of the greatest feats in history. 3/14 http://pbs.twimg.com/media/Fhr34hVWYAEVvqg.jpg

I can understand their skepticism. In some ways we have become a generation accustomed to seeing it all. The bombardment of Hollywood CGI dulled our capacity to be shocked. And current societal divisions leave us often in a state of fatigue and malaise. 2/14 http://pbs.twimg.com/media/Fhr332xWQAk85ti.jpg

Something amazing occurred in Florida last night, but not what‚Äôs leading the news. While political leaders seek to divide us, #Artemis launch pulls us together in new era of discovery. Someone asked me if returning to moon can still inspire. Here‚Äôs what I wish I said back. THREAD http://pbs.twimg.com/media/Fhr33VHXwAIdcsP.jpg

5. Take a look at the 2024 Senate map. Next cycle, about 2/3 of the Senate seats up for grabs are currently held by Democrats. Folks, it's going to be a tough battle to keep the majority. Every seat then, and now, counts.

4. Here's another thing about less 50-50 votes: VP Harris won't have to spend her valuable time sitting around the Senate waiting to break a tie. She can be out in our communities doing the critical work of this Administration.
3. Then there's the obvious one: Votes. In a 50-50 Senate, every single Senator has the power to derail a bill or nominee to get what they want. A 51-49 Senate reduces individual power.

2. Attendance. Senators are human‚Äîwe get sick, have family emergencies, etc. But for the past two years, if even one Senate Democrat was out, we couldn't take party-line votes. 51 Democrats gives us a small, but significant, safety net.

This also means that if Republicans boycott Committees, we can't even take votes to begin with, since we need a simple numerical majority to be able to conduct Committee business. This literally happened earlier this year on the Banking Committee.¬†https://thehill.com/policy/finance/594313-gop-senators-to-block-vote-on-biden-fed-picks/

1. Committee power. In a 50-50 Senate, we govern with a power share agreement, where Committees have an equal number of Democrats & Republicans. That means nominees (like judges) can deadlock and cost floor time to break ties. No ties = faster legislative & confirmation process.
